AI overviews might be reducing traffic following a query, but i strongly suspect the main effect here is a reduction in search queries generally as users increasingly ask their questions to LLMs. It's not just fewer clickthroughs into search results: it's an overall reduction in search queries.

posts.text: In fairness, we're coming at this from different perspectives. You're a lecturer in a math department, so I think your take makes perfect sense. I'm an ML practitioner, so my orientation is more towards the outcome I'm trying to achieve than to any specific formulation of the problem.

reply_context.text: You can talk about convergence without even having a clear idea of what F needs to be.

posts.text: You can talk about convergence without even having a clear idea of what F needs to be.

reply_context.text:
I'd say that operationally, the "real" goal is to achieve desirable performance on some task, and that to frame that task as an optimization problem you define the objective as making F small.

As a concrete example, consider what "convergence" can mean in image generation.

posts.text:
I'd say that operationally, the "real" goal is to achieve desirable performance on some task, and that to frame that task as an optimization problem you define the objective as making F small.

As a concrete example, consider what "convergence" can mean in image generation.

reply_context.text: I have seen some arguments that the 'real' goal of algorithmic optimisation is to reduce the function value, in the sense that if you make F small, then you have done your job. One doesn't have to agree with this, but it does prompt some interesting introspection (IMO).

posts.text: You're not wrong about those three things not being the same, and I think it's not a problem. I'm reasonably confident that in the optimization context, when people talk about "accelerated rates of convergence" it is taken for granted that they mean "the stopping condition for returning a solution".

reply_context.text: To this point, people are often interested in optimisation algorithms that attain "accelerated" rates of convergence. The subtlety is then that you might be able to achieve this for some of these three notions of convergence without achieving it for others.
